comment.author: 22139308@N03
comment._content: Mrs. Adriana Zevenbergen (lit. seven mountains), the 100,000th Dutch migrant after the war, buys a cauliflower from Mrs. Wilhelmina Hofstede in the Australian port of Geelong. Australia, Geelong, March 1959.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: I notice that there is an Aussie named Kelly Zevenbergen on Facebook -- who could, I'm guessing, be this woman's granddaughter? Another photo of the emigrating Zevenbergens is in the Australian National Archives: naa12.naa.gov.au/scripts/PhotoSearchItemDetail.asp?M=0&am... My forebears emigrated from the Netherlands also, coming to Michigan USA in the 1870s. My parents were very excited to return to visit relatives in 1956; they discovered that they could still remember the Dutch language that they had learned as children, from their parents speaking it at home.

comment.author: 8252313@N05
comment._content: Zevenbergen (wiki) is also the name of a town in the Dutch province of Noord-Brabant, which seems like a more logical explanation of her name.

comment.author: 35539988@N07
comment._content:
Wystan - 
i am kelly zevenbergen, the person you refer to on facebook, and yes, Adrianna was my grandmother.  suprisingly you guessed well, there are many zevenbergens in australia, but I am her grand-daughter.  and yhoitink is also correct, zevenbergen is a town in south holland

comment.author: 8252313@N05
comment._content: @kellez79 Nice to hear from you! You can probably find your grandparents in the Nationaal Archief's Australian emigrants database if you're interested.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Well, isn't it fun, to connect across continents in this way! And across time, as well. 'Tis a small world, after all . . . .
